comments:
This course is a continuation of PHYS 101, emphasizing an introduction to
classical electricity and magnetism, relativity theory, optics, and the quantum theory of
matter. It requires a background in calculus.
Overall students were unhappy with this course, but this sentiment was generally a
reflection of the professor. One student noted that the class is a “good survey of second
semester physics concepts,” and another reported enjoying the subject matter, but very
few other students provided qualitative feedback about the course content. Students were
unpleasantly surprised by the amount of calculus required for this intro level physics
course.
Students were rather displeased with Professor Durian. Students described his
lecture style as “boring,” “consistently dull” and “uninspiring.” They noted that he was
both unable to keep students interested, and he was also a very poor communicator of the
material. Students complained that Professor Durian failed to communicate with the TAs
to ensure that quizzes corresponded to what students should expect on exams. Several
students noted that he was “condescending” to students who asked questions in and out of
class. Many reported that they did not find him a fit instructor for an intro level class.
This course fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement. Physics 101 is a
prerequisite for the course, and students must also take a Physics 102 lab concurrently
with this course. This course was suggested by the department for students in a prehealth
program. Exams were described by many students as “much too difficult for an
intro physics course” and “not the least bit straightforward.” A majority of students
complained that the content and difficulty of exams did not at all correspond to the
homework problems or quizzes and also did not reflect the content that was covered in
class or the assigned readings. In addition, lectures focused on theory, while the exams
were largely problems-based. As such, students felt very unprepared for exams.
Students also disliked that there was “no leniency with grading,” such as dropped quizzes
or tests or opportunities for extra credit. In addition, solutions to past exams were only
posted a few days in advance, which “left many students scrambling.”
*Nine students submitted qualitative comments for this course
